Course Title and Instructor
Title: FOR TK: Machine Learning for Prediction: Concepts and Applications in RTime and Place: DAY TIME, LOCATION OR LINK
Instructor: Mike MahoneyEmail: mike.mahoney.218@gmail.comOffice Hours: TK
Description
One hour of lecture/discussion per week. High-level introduction to machine learning centered on predictive applications of supervised learning, with a focus on implementation in R. Topics include: linear and logistic regression, tree-based algorithms (inc. CART, random forests, and gradient boosting machines), support vector machines, and model averaging.
Prerequisites
Students must have some familiarity with the R language, including defining functions, managing objects, controlling the flow of a program (e.g. if/else statements and for-loops), wrangling data in data frames, fitting linear models (i.e., the lm function) and other basic tasks.
An introductory stats course (APM391 or equivalent) is recommended.
Grading
Most weeks, students will be given a hands-on programming assignment due the following class (for a total of 11 assignments). Grades are based solely on assignment performance; there are no quizzes or exams and no attendance or participation requirements. Each assignment is worth an equal number of points (approximately 9% of the final grade).

Textbooks and Materials
This class draws heavily from materials presented in the following two books. Both books are freely available online and you do not need to purchase a physical copy of either book to succeed in this class; there are no assigned readings from these books.
Bradley Boehmke and Brandon Greenwell. (2020). Hands on Machine Learning with R. CRC Press. Available online at https://bradleyboehmke.github.io/HOML/ .
Bradley Efron and Trevor Hastie. (2016). Computer Age Statistical Inference. Cambridge University Press. Available online at https://web.stanford.edu/~hastie/CASI_files/PDF/casi.pdf .
Students will need to have access to a computer they are able to install R packages on.
Attendance Policy
Attendance is not mandatory for this course. Grades will be assigned based on weekly assignments alone; attendance and participation are not incorporated into grades.

Students can contact ODS at 804 University Avenue- Room 309, 315-443-4498 to schedule an appointment and discuss their needs and the process for requesting accommodations. Students may also contact the ESF Office of Student Affairs, 110 Bray Hall, 315-470-6660 for assistance with the process. To learn more about ODS, visit http://disabilityservices.syr.edu. In this course, all people (including but not limited to, people of all races, ethnicities, sexual orientation, gender, gender identity and expression, students undergoing transition, religions, ages, abilities, socioeconomic backgrounds, veteran status, regions and nationalities, intellectual perspectives and political persuasion) are strongly encouraged to respectfully share their unique perspectives and experiences.
